Row.Text: It will grant [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety when completed. It spawns [ICON_RES_WHEAT] Wheat if constructed on a Flood Plain.

Yields [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety when completed. Spawns a source of [ICON_RES_WHEAT] if constructed on a Flood Plain. Cannot be removed and cannot be constructed next to another Obelisk.

An Obelisk can only be built on a Desert tile. It provides additional [ICON_PEACE] Faith and [ICON_JFD_PIETY] Piety, and also spawns a source of [ICON_RES_WHEAT] Wheat if constructed on a Flood Plain. It may not be adjacent to another Obelisk and must be built in Egyptian territory.

Closely related to the French word “Chateau” in meaning, a Schloss is a type of castle that is often used as a sort of second home for nobility. Schlosser were not known for having many defensive components built into them, only really built for purposes of showing off wealth and complementing the nobility’s extravagant lifestyle. In Bavaria in particular, Schlosser were designed to have a classical revival theme around them, with true Enlightenment era architecture. Often, a Schloss would have several other features to give even more of an impression of being incredibly wealthy; a “Wasserschloss”, which loosely translates to “Water Castle”, was simply a Schloss with a moat. This would have been unnecessary for purposes of defense - very few people thought that as an integral part of their castles at the time - but it showed of wealth and grandeur greatly, adding to the romanticism of the design. The interior of these buildings would have also been very nicely decorated, adding to the general feel of the castle as a getaway for the rich. Neuschwanstein Castle - one of the most expensive and luxurious castles build in world history - is known as “Schloss Neuschwanstein” in Germany, making it possibly the strongest contender for the finest example of a Schloss.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A Schloss is a unique improvement available only to Bavaria. It may not be adjacent to another Schloss and can only be constructed on Hills. Whenever a Schloss is constructed, it yields [ICON_GREAT_PEOPLE] Great Musician points for the Capital equal to two times your current [ICON_CULTURE] Culture output. It gains +1 [ICON_CULTURE] Culture for every adjacent Mountain tile. It cannot be removed.
Our people are now spending their days worshipping the sun and sketching themselves as being grossly deformed. We're worried the rest of the world will also succumb to the influence of your culture.

It is not enough that Aten be called the Sun God, for His glory and His wisdom is limitless, and He transcends mere Godhood. All other Gods kneel and quiver in his shadow, for He is Aten the Supreme, the Ultimate, and He is above all else.[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE]Requirement/Restrictions: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Player must be Egypt (Akhenaten) [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Must have a Pantheon [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]May only be enacted once per game [NEWLINE]Costs: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]{1_Num} [ICON_FOOD] Food from the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Temples yield -1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]1 [ICON_MAGISTRATES] Magistrates [NEWLINE]Rewards: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Obelisks yield +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith

It is not enough that Aten be called the Sun God, for His glory and His wisdom is limitless, and He transcends mere Godhood. All other Gods kneel and quiver in his shadow, for He is Aten the Supreme, the Ultimate, and He is above all else.[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE]Costs: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Temples yield -1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith [NEWLINE]Rewards: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Obelisks yield +1 [ICON_PEACE] Faith
{1_LeaderName} of {2_CivName} has declared the {3_CivAdj} Solar Deity, Aten, as Supreme above all.

The Great Aten has commanded of us to construct a temple in his honour! No gold shall be spared in this great endeavour, and, in return, His blessing shall know no bounds.[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE]Requirement/Restrictions: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Player must be Egypt (Akhenaten) [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Must have founded a religion [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]May only be enacted once per game [NEWLINE]Costs: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]{1_Num} [ICON_GOLD] Gold [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]1 [ICON_MAGISTRATES] Magistrates [NEWLINE]Rewards: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Constructs the Gempaaten in the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital

The Great Aten has commanded of us to construct a temple in his honour! No gold shall be spared in this great endeavour, and, in return, His blessing shall know no bounds.[NEWLINE] [NEWLINE]Rewards: [NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Constructs the Gempaaten in the [ICON_CAPITAL] Capital
Contains a slot for a Great Work of Art, Music, and Writing.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]May only be acquired by Egypt under Akhenaten through the "Construct the Gempaaten" decision.

The Gempaaten, or the Temple of Amenhotep IV (also known as Akhenaten), is a temple complex located at Karnak in Luxor, Egypt. Unique to such complexes, the Gempaaten was constructed without a roof, exposing its offering tables to direct sunlight. This is likely to reflect the important status of the Solar Deity, Aten, under Akhenaten; Gempaaten literally means: 'The Sun Disc is Found in the Estate of the God Aten.'
The people of {1_CityName} have invented a new game in which the aim is to roll a ball into a hole. They call this game 'bowling.'

A growing number of priests from the city of {1_CityName} have joined a movement to oppose the indivisible power of the lord Aten. They demand liberties to freely worship their god, {2_GodName}.[NEWLINE]
Aten, giver of life, is the single true God!
Sigh, I'm growing tired on this play, anyway.
[ICON_BULLET][COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]Lose {1_Num} {2_YieldType}[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]A 'We Love the King Day' begins in {3_CityName}[ENDCOLOR]
[ICON_BULLET][COLOR_NEGATIVE_TEXT]Egypt becomes a secular nation[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Gain {1_Num} [ICON_CULTURE] Culture[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Name becomes Amenhotep IV[ENDCOLOR]
We have allowed religious dissidents to worship their gods freely.
We have objected to the free worship of false gods.
We have decided to give up on our worship of Aten.
Distraught over religious dissent, {1_LeaderName} of {2_CivName} has rescinded his devotion to the Egyptian God, Aten.

I asked your father, Mimmureya, for statues of solid cast gold, one of myself and a second statue, a statue of Tadu-Heba (Tadukhepa), my daughter, and your father said, 'Don't talk of giving statues just of solid cast gold. I will give you ones made also of lapis lazuli. I will give you, too, along with the statues, much additional gold and (other) goods beyond measure.' But we have not seen the solid (gold) statues that your father was going to send. You have sent plated ones of wood. Nor have you sent me the goods that your father was going to send me, but you have reduced (them) greatly. Yet there is nothing I know of in which I have failed you. We can only assume that you are a dirty, filthy, lying bastard. With Love, {1_CityStateName}.[NEWLINE]
Ingrates. They should be thankful to get anything.
Relations between {1_CityStateName} and Egypt sour because we were too cheap to give them what was promised.
We must remedy this matter at once.
Relations between {1_CivName} and {2_CityStateName} have soured over claims over swindling.
Relations between {1_CityStateName} and Egypt have informed, for we have honoured them what was promised.
